name: AJEnglish
text:
THREAD üëá

We answer some questions about the transmission of COVID-19 through the air https://t.co/nSQ4SECqoe https://t.co/gCBbVbkcH3

name: AJEnglish
text: While @WHO has said COVID-19 spreads mainly through respiratory droplets, some scientists point out to evidence that the virus can also be transmitted by smaller droplets called aerosols which are usually generated when people are shouting and singing https://t.co/gUl4zEEHt0 https://t.co/mw1HkIgMnQ

name: AJEnglish
text:
@WHO Respiratory droplets sneezed or coughed out are larger in size - a diameter of five to 10 micrometres.

Aerosols, however, are less than five micrometres in diameter and travel beyond two metres from the infected individual https://t.co/v2GLwHNDwE https://t.co/wAjgMkJasY

name: AJEnglish
text:
@WHO As in droplet transmission, airborne transmission can be released through breathing, talking, laughing, sneezing, coughing, singing and shouting.

It can also occur in certain medical procedures, putting healthcare workers particularly at risk https://t.co/v2GLwHNDwE https://t.co/coTlkoW73J

name: AJEnglish
text:
@WHO The extent to which the COVID-19  can be spread by the aerosol route - as opposed to by larger droplets - remains disputed.

But @WHO has acknowledged there was "emerging evidence" of airborne transmission https://t.co/v2GLwHNDwE https://t.co/h4DltAGuth

name: AJEnglish
text:
@WHO How can you protect yourself?

Everyone is recommended to wash hands frequently with soap and water, keep surfaces and objects clean, wear face masks especially in crowded places and maintain a safe distance between themselves and others https://t.co/v2GLwHNDwE https://t.co/XNywuBkdqm
